awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A unique aerogel-based separator technology for safety and ultrafast charging of batteries
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will improve battery market and contribute towards the shift to affordable and clean energy solutions. The company’s novel aerogel membrane separator exhibits performance characteristics that address the major limitations of existing batteries. The enhanced durability and stability provided by the membrane make batteries highly suitable for electric vehicles (EVs) and other applications, such as mobile phones, tablets, drones, cordless power tools, and e-bikes. Electric vehicles offer the most likely solution to reduce the environmental impact of transport in the US by contributing towards a significant reduction in the usage of fossil fuels and the subsequent emissions of greenhouse gases. This technology seeks to improve the overall lifespan of batteries and ensure that they can endure rigorous usage conditions, thereby increasing the reliability and range of EVs, while decreasing the frequency and time of charging and battery replacement. Similarly, in the realm of electronics, the extended battery life translates into enhanced device performance, reduced downtime, and ultimately improved user experience.

This SBIR Phase I project examines the technical feasibility of the company’s aerogel technology as a separator membrane. This membrane is formed by a unique 3-dimensional orientation and functionalization of hexagonal boron nitride sheets (h-BN) combined with boron nitride nanotubes (BNNTs). Current separators are limited by poor thermal stability, subsequently causing the battery industry to face challenges such as long charging times, safety risks associated with high heat generation rates, and low battery performance due to the lack of enough energy capacity. This solution allows for ultra-fast charging (extending the battery rating to 10C) and improved safely (allowing batteries to operate up to 200 °C), while enhancing cyclability, capacity, and power density. The research activities that will allow characterization of the aerogel are functionalization of the membrane with various chemical moieties to enhance ion conductivity, internal series resistance, and lithium plating resistance and investigation and testing of the aerogel pore size formation for a uniform size distribution to prevent lithium plating and penetration of active particles, while maximizing ionic conductivity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Batteries are considered the key energy storage technology of the 21st century and have revolutionized the portable electronics and e-mobility segments. However, current battery performance cannot sustain the increasing power demand. Separators are a key component in all batteries for their impact on performance, safety and cycle life. There have been no significant advancements in membrane separator technology for decades. Commercial batteries with the existing separator technologies are typically unreliable if operated at a higher temperature. Current advancements for high-temperature operation do not fully support ultra-fast charging.

Next-Ion’s technology is the first aerogel separator membrane technology that solves the thermal challenges of batteries, thus allowing safe and ultra-fast charging while enhancing battery capacity and power density. The proprietary separator membrane is constructed from a combination of boron nitride nanotubes (BNNTs) with a boron nitride aerogel (BNAG). The key innovation is the unique orientation and functionalization of 2D sheets of single-atom-thick hexagonal lattice of B & N atoms interconnected to create the 3D porous aerogel embedded with BNNTs. The advantages in chemical inertness, thermal stability, and high surface area of BNAG elevate the reliable and safe battery operation temperature up to 200°C, while maintaining good cyclability, capacity and power density, >10-50% better performance compared to current solutions.

To develop and validate the BNAG membrane as a high-performance battery separator, Next-Ion functionalized the aerogel with various chemical moieties to enhance ion conductivity, internal series resistance and lithium plating resistance. The aerogel’s properties were enhanced by functionalizing, and it resulted in a higher ion transference number (faster charging rate), reduced internal resistance (7x reduction compared to commercial separator) and improved charge efficiency. The aerogel pore size formation was assessed for uniform pore distribution and appropriate porosity which is necessary to mitigate any adverse impact on the mechanical strength and internal resistance of the cell. The aerogel's porosity was successfully controlled at nanoscale precision, achieving uniform pore distribution. Once the pore size and functionalization of the membrane are established, characterization, in-house electrochemical testing, and independent testing were performed. The electrochemical cell measurements demonstrated high specific capacity retention and the safety of chemical reactions enabling safe battery operation with high charging rates and at high temperatures with no thermal runaway. The aerogel separator was validated through rigorous testing at an independent laboratory, confirming its performance at high charging rates, excellent thermal stability and resistance to shrinkage at elevated temperatures compared to traditional separator structures. The production capacity was increased (scalability confirmation) and the feasibility of adapting the early production process for roll-to-roll manufacturing was successfully demonstrated  

Next-Ion aerogel-based separator technology allows the battery to operate at higher temperatures and dis/charge rates, drastically reducing the charging time. It streamlines electric vehicle battery cooling systems due to superior thermal management, allowing for greater cell density per unit area. The self-healing and self-protection mechanisms prevent catastrophic failures such as fires and explosions. Additionally, it elevates battery capacity by and power density, while concurrently slashing costs through efficiency gains in battery cooling systems. Overall, improving batteries' power density, efficiency, and safety via Next-Ion’s novel aerogel-based separator technology will lead to high-performance power tools, anxiety free electric transport, and greater energy storage.
